Becomes prime minister after leading the Conservatives to electoral victory.
Thatcher immediately authorizes forces to recapture the Falklands.
After a few months of fighting, Argentine troops surrender on June 14, 1982.
Wins re-election in a landslide and gains a parliamentary majority with just over 42% of the vote.
The Conservative Party wins its third general election.
Receives the US Medal of Freedom from President George Bush.
Is named a life peer on the Queen's honor list.
Swearing-in ceremony at the House of Lords, where Thatcher formally becomes the Baroness Thatcher of Kesteven.
Formal investiture as chancellor of the College of William and Mary.
Retires from public life after suffering a series of small strokes.
South African police arrest Thatcher's son, Mark, on allegations he was involved in a plot to overthrow the government of Equatorial Guinea.
Mark pleads guilty to unwittingly helping bankroll the coup plot.
In exchange, he receives a fine, a suspended jail sentence and the right to join his family in the United States.
The British National Archives releases the 1979 state papers from Thatcher's early months as prime minister.
